Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: A pilot declares low fuel on approach and needs immediate vectors to the nearest runway.
Story: I was just about to take a sip of my lukewarm coffee when my phone buzzed. It was Jamie, an old college acquaintance, asking if I could recommend a good restaurant nearby for her anniversary dinner. I glanced at the message, feeling the familiar tug of obligation—I’d always been the go-to for local tips, and I knew she expected a thoughtful, quick reply. But before I could type a response, the radio crackled in my headset. “Tower, this is Delta 452, declaring minimum fuel, requesting immediate vectors.” My heart skipped. As an air traffic controller, I knew every second counted. The expectation was clear: pilots’ safety depended on my undivided attention and precise instructions. My mind raced, torn between the friendly expectation to help Jamie and the urgent, life-or-death responsibility in front of me. My fingers hovered over my phone, my other hand gripping the radio. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
